intro: Aragallus viscidulus, commonly known as the sticky aragallus, is a flowering plant native to the Andes Mountains of South America. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants known for their distinctive leaf shapes and often edible or medicinal properties. The plant is characterized by its hairy, glandular stems and leaves that produce a sticky substance, giving it its common name. It typically grows in high-altitude environments, where it thrives in cool, moist conditions. Due to its unique features, it is of interest to botanists and horticulturists studying alpine flora.
